1. Time complexity: The time complexity of the Smith-Waterman algorithm is O(n^2), where n is the length of the shorter sequence. This is because the algorithm needs to compare each element in the shorter sequence with every element in the longer sequence, which leads to a total of n^2 comparisons.
2. Space complexity: The space complexity of the Smith-Waterman algorithm is O(n), where n is the length of the shorter sequence. This is because the algorithm only needs to store the shorter sequence and the corresponding scores for each element in the longer sequence.
3. Worst-case scenario: In the worst-case scenario, the Smith-Waterman algorithm may need to compare each element in the longer sequence with every element in the shorter sequence, which leads to a time complexity of O(n^2). However, in practice, the algorithm typically performs much better than this worst-case scenario, especially for smaller sequences.
4. Average-case scenario: In the average-case scenario, the time complexity of the Smith-Waterman algorithm is typically much faster than O(n^2). This is because the algorithm uses a sliding window approach, which allows it to only compare a small portion of the longer sequence with the shorter sequence at a time. As a result, the time complexity is typically closer to O(n log n) or O(n log log n).
5. Optimal case: In the optimal case, the time complexity of the Smith-Waterman algorithm is O(n log n). This occurs when the sequences are perfectly aligned, and the algorithm only needs to compare each element in the longer sequence with the corresponding element in the shorter sequence.
In summary, the execution time (complexity) of the Smith-Waterman algorithm for the alignment of two sequences depends on the specific implementation and the size of the sequences.
